page.title: 01Gazetteer: Rous Lench
page.content: The land is mainly used for growing crops, e.g. wheat, fodder or for pasture with little dereliction. Very few orchards remain. The area is untypically hilly for this part of England, with mixed woodland covering no more than one fifth, usually the highest ground, around 110 metres. Transport is solely by road. There is but one shop, a farm shop and no post office or schools. Property, including the 5 or so farms are well maintained. About 30% is either half timbered or large, i.e. 18th/19th century vicarage, grange etc. Paraffin is supplied in bulk at the one garage and there is a local coach operator. There was little outside agricultural work to be seen on this November day.A high proportion of the population travel to adjacent towns for their work or education.
